pairs.stoic_text:
XXIII Consider how many different things, whether they concern our
bodies, or our souls, in a moment of time come to pass in every one of
us, and so thou wilt not wonder if many more things or rather all things
that are done, can at one time subsist, and coexist in that both one and
general, which we call the world.
pairs.neutral_text: **23.** Think about how many different processes happen simultaneously in each person - both physical changes in our bodies and mental activities in our minds. When you realize this, you won't be surprised that many more things, or even all events, can happen at the same time and exist together in the single, unified system we call the world.

pairs.stoic_text:
I. Remember how long thou hast already put off these things, and how
often a certain day and hour as it were, having been set unto thee by
the gods, thou hast neglected it. It is high time for thee to understand
the true nature both of the world, whereof thou art a part; and of that
Lord and Governor of the world, from whom, as a channel from the spring,
thou thyself didst flow: and that there is but a certain limit of time
appointed unto thee, which if thou shalt not make use of to calm and
allay the many distempers of thy soul, it will pass away and thou with
it, and never after return.
pairs.neutral_text: Remember how long you have already delayed these important matters, and how many times you have ignored deadlines that were set for you. You need to understand two things: the true nature of the world that you are part of, and the nature of the power that governs the world, which is your source. You have a limited amount of time available to you. If you don't use this time to resolve your mental and emotional problems, your time will run out, you will die, and you won't get another chance.

pairs.stoic_text:
Truly a rare opportunity was given to Marcus Aurelius of showing what
the mind can do in despite of circumstances. Most peaceful of warriors,
a magnificent monarch whose ideal was quiet happiness in home life, bent
to obscurity yet born to greatness, the loving father of children who
died young or turned out hateful, his life was one paradox. That nothing
might lack, it was in camp before the face of the enemy that he passed
away and went to his own place.
pairs.neutral_text: Marcus Aurelius had an unusual chance to demonstrate how mental strength can overcome difficult situations. He was a peaceful person who had to be a military leader, a powerful emperor who preferred simple domestic happiness, someone who wanted privacy but was forced into a prominent role, and a caring father whose children either died early or became unpleasant people. His life was full of contradictions. To complete this pattern, he died in a military camp while facing enemies, rather than at home.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXIV. Lucilla buried Verus; then was Lucilla herself buried by others.
So Secunda Maximus, then Secunda herself. So Epitynchanus, Diotimus;
then Epitynchanus himself. So Antoninus Pius, Faustina his wife; then
Antoninus himself. This is the course of the world. First Celer,
Adrianus; then Adrianus himself. And those austere ones; those that
foretold other men's deaths; those that were so proud and stately, where
are they now? Those austere ones I mean, such as were Charax, and
Demetrius the Platonic, and Eudaemon, and others like unto those. They
were all but for one day; all dead and gone long since. Some of them no
sooner dead, than forgotten. Others soon turned into fables. Of others,
even that which was fabulous, is now long since forgotten. This
thereafter thou must remember, that whatsoever thou art compounded of,
shall soon be dispersed, and that thy life and breath, or thy soul,
shall either be no more or shall ranslated (sp.), and appointed to some
certain place and station.
pairs.neutral_text:
**Section 24:** Lucilla buried her husband Verus, then other people buried Lucilla when she died. The same thing happened with Secunda and Maximus - she buried him, then she died too. Epitynchanus buried Diotimus, then Epitynchanus died. Emperor Antoninus Pius buried his wife Faustina, then Antoninus died. This is how the world works.

First Celer buried Hadrian, then Celer died. What happened to those serious people who predicted when others would die and who acted so proud and important? I'm talking about people like Charax, Demetrius the Platonic philosopher, Eudaemon, and others like them. They only lived for a short time and have all been dead for a long time now. Some were forgotten as soon as they died. Others became legends. Some of those legends have even been forgotten now.

You need to remember that your body will break down and decay soon. Your life, breath, and soul will either stop existing completely or move to some other place.

pairs.stoic_text:
XVII. Whatsoever is, was made for something: as a horse, a vine. Why
wonderest thou? The sun itself will say of itself, I was made for
something; and so hath every god its proper function. What then were
then made for? to disport and delight thyself? See how even common sense
and reason cannot brook it.
pairs.neutral_text: 17. Everything that exists was created for a purpose - for example, a horse serves a function, and so does a vine. Why are you surprised by this? Even the sun would say it was made for a specific purpose, and every god has their own job to do. So what were you created for? Just to have fun and enjoy yourself? You can see that even basic logic and common sense reject this idea.

pairs.stoic_text:
When Marcus succeeded to the throne in 161, the letters begin again,
with slightly increased formality on Fronto's part, and they go on for
some four years, when Fronto, who has been continually complaining of
ill-health, appears to have died. One letter of the later period gives
some interesting particulars of the emperor's public life, which are
worth quoting. Fronto speaks of Marcus's victories and eloquence in the
usual strain of high praise, and then continues.[38]
pairs.neutral_text: When Marcus became emperor in 161, Fronto started writing letters to him again. Fronto wrote in a more formal way than before. The letters continued for about four years until Fronto died. Throughout this time, Fronto had regularly mentioned that his health was poor. One letter from this later period contains useful details about the emperor's public duties. In this letter, Fronto praised Marcus's military successes and speaking skills in his typical manner, then went on to say more.

pairs.stoic_text:
Cynics, a school of philosophers, founded by Antisthenes. Their texts
were a kind of caricature of Socraticism. Nothing was good but virtue,
nothing bad but vice. The Cynics repudiated all civil and social claims,
and attempted to return to what they called a state of nature. Many of
them were very disgusting in their manners.
pairs.neutral_text: The Cynics were a group of philosophers started by Antisthenes. Their writings were an exaggerated version of Socratic philosophy. They believed that only virtue was good and only vice was bad. The Cynics rejected all government and social obligations, and tried to live in what they considered a natural state. Many of them behaved in ways that other people found offensive.

pairs.stoic_text:
X. This, what is it in itself, and by itself, according to its proper
constitution? What is the substance of it? What is the matter, or proper
use? What is the form or efficient cause? What is it for in this world,
and how long will it abide? Thus must thou examine all things, that
present themselves unto thee.
pairs.neutral_text: 10. When you encounter anything, ask yourself these questions: What is this thing actually made of? What is its basic substance or material? What is its purpose or function? What caused it to exist in its current form? Why does it exist in the world, and how long will it last? You should analyze everything you come across using these questions.

pairs.stoic_text:
IV. Have I done anything charitably? then am I benefited by it. See
that this upon all occasions may present itself unto thy mind, and never
cease to think of it. What is thy profession? to be good. And how should
this be well brought to pass, but by certain theorems and doctrines;
some Concerning the nature of the universe, and some Concerning the
proper and particular constitution of man?
pairs.neutral_text: **Section IV.** Did I help someone? If so, I gained something from it. Remember this idea in all situations and keep thinking about it regularly. What is your job in life? To be a good person. How can you do this well? By learning and applying certain principles and teachings - some about how the universe works, and others about human nature and how people are put together.

pairs.stoic_text:
The letter continues with reflections on the nature of death, 'more to
be rejoiced at than bewailed, the younger one dies,' and an arraignment
of Providence not without dignity, wrung from him as it were by this
last culminating misfortune. It concludes with a summing-up of his life
in protest against the blow which has fallen on his grey head.
pairs.neutral_text: The letter goes on to discuss death, saying it should be celebrated rather than mourned, especially when someone dies young. It also criticizes God or fate with some dignity, as if this final major misfortune forced these thoughts from him. The letter ends with him reviewing his life as a way of objecting to this tragedy that has happened to him in his old age.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXXV. Fit and accommodate thyself to that estate and to those
occurrences, which by the destinies have been annexed unto thee; and
love those men whom thy fate it is to live with; but love them truly. An
instrument, a tool, an utensil, whatsoever it be, if it be fit for the
purpose it was made for, it is as it should be though he perchance that
made and fitted it, be out of sight and gone. But in things natural,
that power which hath framed and fitted them, is and abideth within them
still: for which reason she ought also the more to be respected, and we
are the more obliged (if we may live and pass our time according to her
purpose and intention) to think that all is well with us, and according
to our own minds. After this manner also, and in this respect it is,
that he that is all in all doth enjoy his happiness.
pairs.neutral_text:
**35.** Accept your life situation and the events that happen to you, since these are determined by fate. Love the people you must live with, and love them genuinely. 

Any tool or instrument works properly when it serves its intended purpose, even if the person who made it is no longer around. But with natural things, the force that created and shaped them continues to exist within them. For this reason, we should respect this force more, and we have a greater obligation to think everything is going well for us if we can live according to this natural purpose. 

This is how someone who accepts everything completely finds happiness.

pairs.stoic_text:
[12]'What spirit do you suppose is in me, when I remember how long it
is since I have seen you, and why I have not seen you! and it may be
I shall not see you for a few days yet, while you are strengthening
yourself; as you must. So while you lie on the sick-bed, my spirit also
will lie low anti, whenas,[13] by God's mercy you shall stand upright,
my spirit too will stand firm, which is now burning with the strongest
desire for you. Farewell, soul of your prince, your pupil.'
pairs.neutral_text: I feel troubled when I think about how long it has been since I last saw you and the reason why we haven't met. I may not be able to see you for several more days while you recover your strength, which you need to do. While you rest in bed during your illness, I will also feel low in spirits. When God helps you get well and you can stand up again, my spirits will also recover. Right now, I have a strong desire to see you. Goodbye, dear soul of your prince and student.

pairs.stoic_text:
IX. It is not possible that any nature should be inferior unto art,
since that all arts imitate nature. If this be so; that the most perfect
and general nature of all natures should in her operation come short of
the skill of arts, is most improbable. Now common is it to all arts, to
make that which is worse for the better's sake. Much more then doth the
common nature do the same. Hence is the first ground of justice. From
justice all other virtues have their existence. For justice cannot be
preserved, if either we settle our minds and affections upon worldly
things; or be apt to be deceived, or rash, and inconstant.
pairs.neutral_text: IX. No natural process can be inferior to human art, because all arts copy nature. If this is true, then it would be very unlikely for nature—which is the most complete and universal of all natural systems—to perform worse than human skills. All arts commonly create inferior things to serve better purposes. Nature does this even more. This is the basic foundation of justice. All other virtues come from justice. Justice cannot exist if we focus our thoughts and desires on material things, or if we are easily fooled, impulsive, or unreliable.

pairs.stoic_text:
XV. In the morning as soon as thou art awaked, when thy judgment, before
either thy affections, or external objects have wrought upon it, is yet
most free and impartial: put this question to thyself, whether if that
which is right and just be done, the doing of it by thyself, or by
others when thou art not able thyself; be a thing material or no. For
sure it is not. And as for these that keep such a life, and stand so
much upon the praises, or dispraises of other men, hast thou forgotten
what manner of men they be? that such and such upon their beds, and such
at their board: what their ordinary actions are: what they pursue after,
and what they fly from: what thefts and rapines they commit, if not with
their hands and feet, yet with that more precious part of theirs, their
minds: which (would it but admit of them) might enjoy faith, modesty,
truth, justice, a good spirit.
pairs.neutral_text:
15. When you wake up in the morning, your thinking is clearest before your emotions or outside influences affect you. At this time, ask yourself: Does it matter whether you or someone else does the right thing, as long as the right thing gets done? The answer is no, it doesn't matter.

As for people who live only for others' approval or criticism, remember what they're really like. Think about how they act in private - in their bedrooms and at their dinner tables. Consider what they actually want and what they avoid. They steal and take things, maybe not with their hands, but with their minds and thoughts. If they chose differently, their minds could instead have faith, modesty, truth, justice, and goodness.

pairs.stoic_text:
Aurelius and of his colleague L. Verus in their boyhood; and he was
rewarded for his efforts by a seat in the Senate and the consular rank
(A.D. 143). By the exercise of his profession he became wealthy; and if
he speaks of his means as not great,[2] he must be comparing his wealth
with the grandees of Rome, not with the ordinary citizen.
pairs.neutral_text: Marcus Aurelius and his colleague L. Verus were taught by this person when they were children. Because of his teaching work, he was given a position in the Senate and the rank of consul in 143 A.D. His job as a teacher made him rich. When he said his wealth was not very large, he was probably comparing himself to the wealthiest people in Rome, not to regular citizens.

pairs.stoic_text:
IX. Repentance is an inward and self-reprehension for the neglect or
omission of somewhat that was profitable. Now whatsoever is good, is
also profitable, and it is the part of an honest virtuous man to set by
it, and to make reckoning of it accordingly. But never did any honest
virtuous man repent of the neglect or omission of any carnal pleasure:
no carnal pleasure then is either good or profitable.
pairs.neutral_text: 9. Repentance happens when you blame yourself for failing to do something that would have benefited you. Anything that is good is also beneficial, and a moral person values good things and treats them as important. However, no moral person has ever regretted missing out on physical pleasures. Therefore, physical pleasures are neither good nor beneficial.

pairs.stoic_text:
LI. He that knoweth not what the world is, knoweth not where he himself
is. And he that knoweth not what the world was made for, cannot possibly
know either what are the qualities, or what is the nature of the world.
Now he that in either of these is to seek, for what he himself was made
is ignorant also. What then dost thou think of that man, who proposeth
unto himself, as a matter of great moment, the noise and applause
of men, who both where they are, and what they are themselves, are
altogether ignorant? Dost thou desire to be commended of that man, who
thrice in one hour perchance, doth himself curse himself? Dost thou
desire to please him, who pleaseth not himself? or dost thou think that
he pleaseth himself, who doth use to repent himself almost of everything
that he doth?
pairs.neutral_text:
51. If you don't understand what the world is, you don't know where you are. If you don't understand the world's purpose, you can't know its qualities or nature. Someone who lacks this knowledge also doesn't understand their own purpose. 

Why would you care about getting praise and approval from people who don't understand where they are or what they are? Do you want approval from someone who criticizes himself three times in an hour? Do you want to please someone who doesn't please himself? Do you think someone who regrets almost everything he does is actually satisfied with himself?

pairs.stoic_text:
III. Think thyself fit and worthy to speak, or to do anything that is
according to nature, and let not the reproach, or report of some that
may ensue upon it, ever deter thee. If it be right and honest to be
spoken or done, undervalue not thyself so much, as to be discouraged
from it. As for them, they have their own rational over-ruling part, and
their own proper inclination: which thou must not stand and look
about to take notice of, but go on straight, whither both thine own
particular, and the common nature do lead thee; and the way of both
these, is but one.
pairs.neutral_text: **III.** Consider yourself capable and deserving to speak or act in ways that align with nature. Don't let criticism or negative reactions from others stop you. If something is right and good to say or do, don't underestimate yourself to the point where you avoid it. Other people have their own reasoning abilities and personal preferences, which you shouldn't concern yourself with observing or analyzing. Instead, continue directly on the path that both your individual nature and universal human nature guide you toward - these two paths are actually the same.

pairs.stoic_text:
XI. To find out, and set to thyself some certain way and method of
contemplation, whereby thou mayest clearly discern and represent unto
thyself, the mutual change of all things, the one into the other. Bear
it in thy mind evermore, and see that thou be throughly well exercised
in this particular. For there is not anything more effectual to beget
true magnanimity.
pairs.neutral_text: **11.** Develop a specific method for observing how all things constantly change and transform into other things. Always keep this in mind and practice it regularly. Nothing else is more effective for developing genuine courage and strength of character.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXXI. As long as the foot doth that which belongeth unto it to do, and
the hand that which belongs unto it, their labour, whatsoever it be, is
not unnatural. So a man as long as he doth that which is proper unto
a man, his labour cannot be against nature; and if it be not against
nature, then neither is it hurtful unto him. But if it were so that
happiness did consist in pleasure: how came notorious robbers, impure
abominable livers, parricides, and tyrants, in so large a measure to
have their part of pleasures?
pairs.neutral_text:
When a foot does what feet are supposed to do and a hand does what hands are supposed to do, their work is natural, regardless of what that work is. Similarly, when a person does what humans are meant to do, their actions are not against nature. If something is not against nature, then it cannot harm them.

But if happiness really came from pleasure, then why do famous criminals, people who live immoral lives, murderers of their own parents, and dictators experience so much pleasure?

pairs.stoic_text:
XI. Of things that are external, happen what will to that which can
suffer by external accidents. Those things that suffer let them complain
themselves, if they will; as for me, as long as I conceive no such
thing, that that which is happened is evil, I have no hurt; and it is in
my power not to conceive any such thing.
pairs.neutral_text: 11. External events can only harm things that are capable of being affected by outside circumstances. If those things want to complain about what happens to them, they can do so. As for me, as long as I don't think that what happened is bad, I'm not harmed. And I have the ability to choose not to think of it as bad.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXVII. If in this kind of life thy body be able to hold out, it is a
shame that thy soul should faint first, and give over, take heed, lest
of a philosopher thou become a mere Cæsar in time, and receive a new
tincture from the court. For it may happen if thou dost not take heed.
Keep thyself therefore, truly simple, good, sincere, grave, free
from all ostentation, a lover of that which is just, religious, kind,
tender-hearted, strong and vigorous to undergo anything that becomes
thee. Endeavour to continue such, as philosophy (hadst thou wholly and
constantly applied thyself unto it) would have made, and secured thee.
Worship the Gods, procure the welfare of men, this life is short.
Charitable actions, and a holy disposition, is the only fruit of this
earthly life.
pairs.neutral_text:
**Section 27:** If your body can handle this way of life, don't let your mind give up first. Be careful not to gradually change from being a philosopher into just another politician who gets corrupted by power and court life. This can happen if you're not paying attention.

Stay genuinely simple, good, honest, serious, and unpretentious. Love justice, be religious, kind, compassionate, and strong enough to handle whatever duties you have. Try to remain the kind of person that philosophy would have shaped you into if you had fully committed to it.

Honor the gods and help other people. Life is brief. The only worthwhile results from this earthly existence are acts of kindness and maintaining a moral character.

pairs.stoic_text:
XVII. The nature of the universe, of the common substance of all things
as it were of so much wax hath now perchance formed a horse; and then,
destroying that figure, hath new tempered and fashioned the matter of it
into the form and substance of a tree: then that again into the form and
substance of a man: and then that again into some other. Now every one
of these doth subsist but for a very little while. As for dissolution,
if it be no grievous thing to the chest or trunk, to be joined together;
why should it be more grievous to be put asunder?
pairs.neutral_text: The universe is made of a common substance that can be reshaped into different forms, like wax. This substance might first form a horse, then be broken down and reformed into a tree, then into a human, then into something else. Each form only exists for a short time. If it's not harmful for parts to come together to form something, then it shouldn't be harmful for them to separate either.

pairs.stoic_text:
XXIV. Out of Antisthenes. 'It is a princely thing to do well, and to be
ill-spoken of. It is a shameful thing that the face should be subject
unto the mind, to be put into what shape it will, and to be dressed by
it as it will; and that the mind should not bestow so much care upon
herself, as to fashion herself, and to dress herself as best becometh
her.'
pairs.neutral_text: **24. From Antisthenes.** "It's noble to do the right thing even when people criticize you for it. It's shameful that we spend so much time controlling our facial expressions and appearance to look how we want, but we don't put the same effort into improving our character and mindset."

pairs.stoic_text:
XLI. As the ordinary shows of the theatre and of other such places,
when thou art presented with them, affect thee; as the same things still
seen, and in the same fashion, make the sight ingrateful and tedious;
so must all the things that we see all our life long affect us. For all
things, above and below, are still the same, and from the same causes.
When then will there be an end?
pairs.neutral_text: When you go to the theater or similar entertainment venues, you initially enjoy the shows. But when you see the same performances repeatedly in the same way, they become boring and unpleasant to watch. This same principle applies to everything we experience throughout our lives. All things in the world - whether important or trivial - remain essentially the same and result from the same underlying causes. So when will this repetitive cycle finally stop?

pairs.stoic_text:
The Stoics regarded speculation as a means to an end and that end was,
as Zeno put it, to live consistently (ὁμολογουμένος ζῆν), or as it was
later explained, to live in conformity with nature (ὁμολογουμένος τῇ
φύσει ζῆν). This conforming of the life to nature was the Stoic idea of
Virtue. This dictum might easily be taken to mean that virtue consists
in yielding to each natural impulse; but that was very far from the
Stoic meaning. In order to live in accord with nature, it is necessary
to know what nature is; and to this end a threefold division of
philosophy is made—into _Physics_, dealing with the universe and its
laws, the problems of divine government and teleology; _Logic_, which
trains the mind to discern true from false; and _Ethics_, which applies
the knowledge thus gained and tested to practical life.
pairs.neutral_text:
The Stoics viewed philosophical thinking as a tool to achieve a specific goal. According to Zeno, this goal was to live consistently, or as later Stoics explained, to live according to nature. The Stoics believed that living according to nature was the same as being virtuous.

This idea might seem to suggest that virtue means following every natural urge, but the Stoics did not mean this at all. They believed that to live according to nature, a person must first understand what nature actually is. To gain this understanding, they divided philosophy into three areas:

1. Physics - the study of the universe, its laws, how divine forces govern it, and its purpose
2. Logic - training the mind to tell the difference between what is true and what is false  
3. Ethics - using the knowledge from physics and logic in everyday life

pairs.stoic_text:
Here and there we meet with allusions to his daily life, which we could
wish to be more frequent. He goes to the theatre or the law-courts,[31]
or takes part in court ceremony, but his heart is always with his
books. The vintage season, with its religious rites, was always spent by

He attended theater performances, visited law courts, and participated in official court events, but he was always more interested in reading and studying. Antoninus Pius always spent the grape harvest season in the countryside, where he took part in the traditional religious ceremonies. The letters that follow show what he typically did during a day at that time.

pairs.stoic_text:
VI. These things thou must always have in mind: What is the nature
of the universe, and what is mine--in particular: This unto that what
relation it hath: what kind of part, of what kind of universe it is: And
that there is nobody that can hinder thee, but that thou mayest always
both do and speak those things which are agreeable to that nature,
whereof thou art a part.
pairs.neutral_text: 6. Always remember these points: What is the nature of the universe, and what is my own nature. Specifically, understand how these two relate to each other - what kind of part I am within what kind of whole system. Remember that no one can prevent you from acting and speaking in ways that align with the nature you are part of.

pairs.stoic_text:
VIII. To grow together like fellow branches in matter of good
correspondence and affection; but not in matter of opinions. They that
shall oppose thee in thy right courses, as it is not in their power to
divert thee from thy good action, so neither let it be to divert thee
from thy good affection towards them. But be it thy care to keep thyself
constant in both; both in a right judgment and action, and in true
meekness towards them, that either shall do their endeavour to hinder
thee, or at least will be displeased with thee for what thou hast done.
For to fail in either (either in the one to give over for fear, or in
the other to forsake thy natural affection towards him, who by nature is
both thy friend and thy kinsman) is equally base, and much savouring of
the disposition of a cowardly fugitive soldier.
pairs.neutral_text:
**8. Stay united with others in friendship and cooperation, but not necessarily in beliefs.**

When people oppose your right actions, they cannot force you to stop doing good things. Similarly, don't let them make you stop caring about them as people. Focus on staying consistent in two areas: making good decisions and taking right actions, while also remaining kind toward those who try to stop you or who get upset with you for your choices.

Failing in either area is equally wrong. If you give up doing what's right because you're afraid, that's a problem. If you stop caring about someone who is naturally your friend and fellow human being, that's also a problem. Both responses are weak and cowardly, like a soldier who runs away from battle.

pairs.stoic_text:
as industry in one, in another modesty, in another bountifulness, in
another some other thing. For nothing can so much rejoice thee, as
the resemblances and parallels of several virtues, eminent in the
dispositions of them that live with thee, especially when all at once,
as it were, they represent themselves unto thee. See therefore, that

pairs.neutral_text: When you observe people around you, you'll notice that each person excels in different virtues - one person might be hardworking, another humble, another generous, and so on. Nothing will give you more satisfaction than noticing these various good qualities in the people you interact with, particularly when you can see multiple virtues displayed at the same time. Make sure you stay aware of and remember these positive examples.
